properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

This line has a history of producing wind gusts of 35 to 45 knots. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds will reach up to 90 kilometres per hour beginning tonight. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow today. Additional snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 cm are expected before the snow tapers off early this afternoon. Northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will give local blowing and drifting snow, particularly over exposed areas. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T22:59:01-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief strong wind gusts possible today. A strong cold front will sweep across the region today preceded by a band of scattered showers and thunderstorms. The band will affect areas near Georgian Bay in the late morning or around noon, then move rapidly eastward to reach eastern Ontario in the mid afternoon. Winds gusts near or in excess of 90 km/h will be possible in some areas as the band moves through. Given that the showers and thunderstorms are expected to be scattered, strong wind gusts will only affect some areas. Where these strong winds develop, local power outages will be possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-21T01:59:41-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall followed by heavy rain is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: southern and western Newfoundland. Total snowfall: generally 2 to 4 cm. Total rainfall: 30 to 60 mm in the south and 15 to 25 mm in the west. Time span: until overnight tonight in the west and southwest, and tonight in the south. Remarks: Rain at times heavy in the southwest will spread elsewhere this evening. Conditions will improve by Saturday morning. Strong southerly winds and mild temperatures will accompany the rainfall to cause significant snowmelt and runoff, leading to potential flooding. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-21T10:21:27-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and rapidly falling temperatures today. The snow will taper off by this evening, with total snowfall amounts up to 10 cm expected. This morning, a cold front will sweep through with a fairly dramatic temperature drop from near zero degrees to well below. This may result in icy conditions on untreated surfaces. Gusty winds up to 60 km/h may also result in isolated power outages. If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall amounts: 20 to 40 cm. Peak wind gusts: northwesterly 110 km/h. Locations: Postville-Makkovik to Natuashish. Time span: tonight through Saturday. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will persist through tonight and Saturday. Strong northwesterly winds will develop overnight tonight in the Natuashish area and will spread south to Postville-Makkovik by Saturday afternoon. These winds will combine with the fresh snowfall to reduce visibility at times to near zero in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Saturday night as the snow tapers off the winds begin to ease. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-21T10:45:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-20T18:46:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1697570429.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall amounts: 20 to 30 cm. Peak wind gusts: northwesterly 100 km/h. Locations: Black Tickle to Rigolet. Time span: tonight through Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will persist through tonight and Saturday. Strong northwesterly winds will develop Saturday afternoon and will combine with the fresh snowfall to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Saturday night as the snow tapers off the winds begin to ease. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
